alert.note: Alert for Western Siskiyou National Forest (Oregon) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Medford (Southwest Oregon and Northern California)
info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued September 14 at 3:13AM PDT until September 14 at 8:00AM PDT by NWS Medford
info.description: ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 AM PDT THIS MORNING FOR EAST WIND WITH POOR OVERNIGHT RH RECOVERY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONE 619... * IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended. Northeast to east winds will be gusty through early Thursday morning, then weaken. But, humidity recovery will be moderate to poor through early Sunday morning. The hazard is in effect into early Thursday morning due to the combination of gusty wind and low humidity. * AFFECTED AREA...Oregon fire weather zone 619, including the Kalmiopsis Wilderness, and western portion of the Siskiyou National Forest. This is mainly the higher terrain of Curry County, but extends into far western Josephine County and far southern Coos County. This includes the Anvil and Flat wildfires. * WIND...Northeast to east 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 35 mph. * HUMIDITY...Maximum humidity of 25 to 35 percent is expected early Thursday morning. * DETAILED URL...View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
info.instruction: Avoid tossing burning cigarettes on the ground, parking hot vehicles on dry vegetation, and using equipment that can cause sparks. Follow all fire restrictions. Find links to restrictions at weather.gov/medford/wildfire. One less spark, one less wildfire. Gather your fire evacuation kit now. Collect essentials you don`t want to lose and prioritize your checklist. Visit ready.gov/kit for more information. Familiarize yourself with your evacuation plan. Where will you go? How will you get there? Who will you call to let others know your are safe? Visit ready.gov/wildfires for more information. A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now or will shortly. These conditions promote rapid spread of fire which may become life threatening. Evacuate if ordered to, or if a fire threatens.
